posts.com:
You're still young. 22 is still in the "your entire life ahead of you" zone.

Having drawn a lot as a kid obviously helps, but if you just want to draw well, you can achieve that quite feasibly over the course of a few years. While obviously you have your cases of prodigies and savants or whatever, we're not dealing with the extraordinary here. Most kids that spend a ton of time drawing don't know how to pick up skills and at best just develop a few healthy habits, making their growth relatively negligible compared to a couple of years of thoughtful study and application.

Cut yourself some slack and get to work.

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6430778

Some resources:
/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

Books:
Understanding Comics
Making Comics
Manga in Theory and Practice: The Craft of Creating Manga
https://mega.nz/folder/Dd4hnZTC#EjMIcTDPLbWXkAJLPHx2Kg
Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting
https://archive.org/details/RobertMcKeeStorypdf/
Even a Monkey Can Draw Manga
https://kupdf.net/download/even-a-monkey-can-draw-manga_58b9ca16e12e89233badd376_pdf
The Shonen Jump Guide to Making Manga
https://mega.nz/file/i81imLpI#GcheJ9Jjk3lw1RE9nQWgL4RG4wEBNOcRmgA-iaU6Wpg

https://www.naokiurasawa.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:
> https://jasonthibault.com/definitive-list-comic-publisher-submission-guidelines/
> https://writingtipsoasis.com/best-independent-comic-book-publishers/

And a new addition, not technically a publisher, but a new platform to host your manga:

Manga Plus Creators by Shueisha
https://medibang.com/mpc/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6449929
It's very good for making manga (page by page format) and webtoons (scrolling format).
Pretty much every professional that makes manga digitally uses it.
It has all the tools you need and the free assets store has a ton of stuff to make the creation process even easier like premade speech bubbles, manga backgrounds, effects brushes, 3d models and so on.
My only gripe with clipstudio is that the lettering system is so barebones that it hurts.
It gets the job done but it does feel very clunky doing your lettering in clipstudio.
I've only made comics in paint tool sai before and compared to that clipstudio is so much better.
Also there's a ton of tutorials on the creation process both official and by fans on youtube.
Just buy it on a sale.

They probably used something like blender to model and design these assets. Do the donut tutorial to get familiar with the interface and basic modelling + look into array modifiers and how to apply textures. That alone can help you get as far as how Shadows House got.

Most mangaka and artists probably buy 3d models off of websites like a Japanese equivalent of Daz3d and import them to CSP. CSP also readily supplies some 3d assets for free, and I believe there are some user-made content you can purchase too.

posts.com:
Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6443881
>read pen & ink by guptill, it's literally what mangakas study
>take a few pieces of lineart from an artist you like and try to do a study from like where you imitate the style of rendering on a more simplistic object
>do a rough sketch and then try different line techniques on another layer, then try drawing another version w/o the underdrawing
what helped me a lot was taking a month where i only drew w/ the binary brush & eraser on one layer while trying to limit undos (ideally none at all) the drawings sucked compared to my normal work & were way harder at first but i learned an absolute shitton and became way more confident about working without crutches

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Art used to have value for it's scarcity and originality, the fact that now can be quickly produced makes each piece to be worth very little.

Focusing the value of art as the Japanese do (technical measurable parameters) was a mistake, it was scarcity and originality what made art worth.

By over-saturating the internet with art you are causing something similar to inflation, art is now worthless, like those African banknotes, it can be produced by thousands and it will always have correct perspective, lighting, anatomy etc.

It is doing the opposite of what crypto and NFTs were supposed to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428037
Jdownloader2 is a download manager. It automatically saves links from direct download hosts when you copy them and organizes them in a queue. You can then choose when you want the downloads to start. It has many other functions, such as downloading all images from 4chan threads, or from Sadpanda, or saving Youtube videos with subtitles. It can also encode links in a "DLC" file, which offers a layer of protection for those files.
Even though JDownloader2 is free and open source software, the installer is often packaged with adware from places like CNet. The JAR version is just a self-extracting java-based zip file, which in theory is adware free.
I make no guarantees. Scan every software you download and make sure you read installation screens carefully, all the usual things you should be doing already.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6448071

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6448467
Rushed this one out, sorry, but essentially it boils down to two things, anon. Contrast, and grouping. Your values/shadows essentially are the result of form and light. Right now you're adding unnecessary detail in areas that should be low detail, like the belly. You're leaving small light spots that attract our attention where it shouldn't be (if the tummy should be the highlight you'd need a different composition.)

When you think about values and light you should think of the painting as a whole. Unless it's concept art, a middle range value lile the one you picked for your painting is a pretty bad place to start, because already the whole composition is pretty much in the same value range. Especially early you shouldn't be afraid of really pushing the value range, somdare to go much darker and much lighter.

Keep your light sourse in mind. And what the light itself /is/. Different types of light will cause different shadows to be created. Harsh sunlight, for example, causes fairly dark but warm coloured shadows and might cause light to bounce off large surfaces. So a chin, which is pointing downwards but juts out might cast a lighter shadow than the nect area, as light is being reflected off of the ground. This is why thinking of form is also very important.

posts.com:
>>6444277
>Am I actively harming my learning by using her as my reference?
Sadly, you are, since this and most 3D models have various limitations.

Muscles expand and contract in different ways from pose-to-pose that the doll isn't able to replicate here. Even AAA games have only just started to simulate stuff like this.
Since the model lacks detail you're also not seeing how the different muscles or bones might become more visible in certain poses.
(Even if you wouldn't always draw these details in a heavily stylized work it's still important to be aware of them.)
The lighting in this scene is also very soft, which works for making the model look good, but makes for a poor shading reference as the plane changes in the body aren't as clear.
Also due to rigging limitations the doll won't always contort correctly into certain poses.
By solely referencing this model you're also copying all anatomical mistakes done by the original artist.

As you don't have an accurate reference of the human body, your learning is also inaccurate.
I'd recommend grabbing a cheap professional reference pack from ArtStation, for example. I'm sure you should be able to find a model you like.

>>6450506
>>6450693
i'm by no means an expert but i think you could try focusing on two things first:
- drawing the major curves of the pose (e.g. gesture), most often this will be things like the spine curve, the angle of the hips and shoulders, the flow of the limbs
- drawing simple 3d forms like boxes and cylinders, being aware of which side is facing you and which side is facing away from you, then break the figure down into simple boxes and cylinders and try to give yourself a sense of which blocks are coming towards you or heading away, etc

Hi anon, used one of the figures you posted as part of my figure drawing today. Then I broke it into more explicit box forms. When drawing the figure on the left, I’m thinking about the forms and also about the shapes on the figure in a hybrid sort of way.

I’ll also throw my hat into the giving you advice ring, feel free to take or leave it:
I question labelling >>6450413 this one here as ‘symbol drawing’. from what I can see you’ve attempted to reproduce the shapes as you see them on the figure, which is great! I think the other anon just correctly saw that your 3-dimensional understanding of the forms in the figure was lacking. So definitely take the advice given to you about breaking the figure into forms, practice your boxes etc. But, as far as I can see, doing studies faithfully reproducing the shapes you see on the figure will do you no harm.
Rather, symbol drawing is the subconscious refusal to draw the figure as you actually see it. And that’s something that’ll haunt you well outside of being a beg. Constantly catching myself symbol drawing, as well as in this study I did here.

>>6451772
Books and poetry are indeed art. Prompts are not. Prompts are more fundamental. The same prompt might generate many types of arts.

It's like I wanted to copyright blue + yellow color combination. Many arts can be made with those 2 colors. Same with music. You're free to pick any scale and any of the notes to create your art with any instrument. Just because you use 3 chords from the available pool of options, does not give you rights to the chords itself.

You can make a point of owning the final art of a prompt, the ones you generate with it. But the prompt itself is not art, it does not matter how complex it is. It is a tool that anyone can use, and it can generate art for them that are different from yours.

happy new year. I am back with an interesting find.

In a past post, I mentioned that mangakas tend to copy each other in things they consider work and can apply to their own work. That's how it's always been.

I forgot to mention that the format of work for artists often incorporates assistants who, with time, adopt the style and take on features whether they want it or not, from the mangaka they work for until they manage to go independent.


Now check this:

https://nhentai.net/g/546/
https://exhentai.org/g/2045223/2ae1ebbce9/
https://exhentai.org/g/2341/c7f27363b8/
All links belong to [Kago Shintarou] Choutennou Parataxis | Super-Conductive Brains Parataxis [English]

It's an 2001 tankoubon with excellent panel clarity and readability (despite the low resolution scans).
But what interests me is the striking resemblance to Masamune Shirow's style from the late 1980s and early 1990s.
It's almost a "love letter to the author" during the first 2 chapters, with uncanny similitude in design language (character designs, expressions and objects) and mixing it with his own style evident in the rest of the tank.
I leave you with the GITS 1.5 because the one i found for the original is a mirrored edition. couldn't find the correct orientation and B&W, but it is still useful for reference.
https://mangasee123.com/manga/Ghost-In-The-Shell-15

According to my knowledge and limited research, they both have never worked together, but you'd never know given how reserved Masamune is.

By the way, speaking of Shirow Masamune. Check out pic related and then link bellow if you think stylized bodies are a detached image from reality.
https://www.pornhub.com/view_video.php?viewkey=ph55876fe18e4fb
oiled, and all

If your goal is solely the end result, that is, if you just need a way to generate an image from what you have in your head, there's no reason to dedicate years of your life on drawing.
Now, I think that, in any human activity, the way if affects us is as important as the way we employ it to affect the world. If you spend years drawing it will mold you into a whole different person, change the way you experience reality, just like any other activity. I must say that practicing art makes life more beautiful; your vision is different and this difference expresses itself in the way you are, think, speak, act, everything. This transformation cannot be reproduced by an algorithm. But you just do it everyday and love it.

>>6367918
Depends on the colors and obviously on the pigment, let's just say that even on artist grade gouache they're very liberal with their lightfastness grading. Traditional gouache was never meant to be archival, it doesn't form a film once it dries, it's chalky and gets dirty fast unless you put it under glass, it's was meant for illustrators to quickly turn their artwork, photograph it for publishing and forget about it.
General speaking you should worry about the pinks but there are colors that people not suspect like raw sienna and yellow ochre, they will get grayer, unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Even acrylic will shift, I have Golden Fluid Yellow Ochre and it shifted to gray months later. Any color that looks saturated and vibrant won't stay that way for long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

it's not an alternative to thinners. it's more of an alternative to fluid and gel mediums like sunthickened linseed oil or maroger medium. while thinners lower the oil content, fluid and gel mediums increase the oil content.
one should not use too much thinner because pigments lose binder.
one should not use too much fluid/gel medium because the pigments have too much binder and can cause problems like wrinkling or yellowing depending on the medium.

G pen is good option if you don't like fineliner. Maru nibs is an option for thinner lines. Dip pen need a lot of practice and kinda messy at first. Stick with Japanese brands.
Also try to use brush and ink, the only problem is they can't really use waterproof ink, otherwise it's pretty flexible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

>>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415075

The sets are bad, you're paying a lot for hues that don't play well together.

Only get the SKETCH markers, not the Classic or Ciao. Start with a cool/neutral/warm gray set depending on your style and needs, they can be used as a base with other hues.

Then buy a set of singles with similar color intensities and ID's. Check this guide to make sense of the ID system: https://markernovice.com/copic/copic-numbering

If you're going for realism you're not going to want all the intense candy shades, plus that the hue samples usually look lighter than they'll end up on your paper/pad after several strokes, and a lot of the really lighter shades (X000 etc) can be used to mix with other hues for great effect.

So for a range of blues you might want B21 Baby Blue, B91 Night Blue, B37 Antwerp Blue, B61 Light Hydrangea, instead of the intense ones like B29 Ultramarine, B16 Caynine Blue or B06 Peacock Blue. You can easily get by with a set of 3-4 in each hue range, some skintones, some ultralights, which might amount to 20 or so markers total. A lot cheaper than 72 goofball hues that don't blend well.

You'll get a blender with a gray set but it's not what you think, blending is done by carefully connecting two adjacent hues and not with the blender marker, it's more of an FX thing that'll wet your strokes and turn them abit watercolory.

>>6426165
For dry drawing media, I use a silver point. My favorite surface is fine Carrara marble dust that is mixed with Dutch lead white which has been ground in vinegar and washed, sometimes tinted with other pigments. For darker lines, some pumice or quartz. For the glue, I choose parchment size mixed with a solution of potash alum.
For the ink to use with natural quill, I take the shavings of red sandalwood or brazilwood and heat it gently in well water, which afterwards is mixed with gum arabic and a pinch of potash alum. I add a drop of clove oil as a preservative.

posts.com:
>>6428703
I can't see any of those videos, only the thumbnails because I don't have an Instagram account, but it looks like he uses a fair bit of line weight.
Fineliners are alright and very straightforward for a beginner to use since they always have a single constant width but they won't get you natural line variation, you'll need to manually thicken the line by drawing over it. Their lines can feel very mechanical otherwise, which is only natural considering they're like a disposable version of technical drawing pens.
Fineliners don't shatter under your hand or anything, but they tend to be inconsistent and start having ink flow problems with time, requiring you to hold them very vertically to keep working. The problem is compounded if you happen to be heavy-handed, so if you think that might end up a problem it might be a good idea to pick up Uni-pins instead since they have very durable tips.
But Microns are perfectly well-loved pens as far as their type goes. If you're in for even and consistent lines it's what fineliners will give you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428775
Mangaka mainly use dip pens (pic rel), but they're difficult to control and can be a bit hard to find. Bristle brush pens and proper brushes have the most line variation and they're what's behind most of those 熱血 crazy-looking thick lines in drawings by animators like Umakoshi and Hayama. They're also very difficult to control. The difficulty can be a good thing if you want to challenge yourself and train your dexterity, but it could get frustrating for a beginner.
Felt tip brush pens are comparatively really easy to control and you can still get good line variety out of them. I've never used the Micron one but it's probably fine.
A lot of manga artists do use fineliners, but it's usually for details, hatching or speech bubbles. Maru nibs produce similarly thin lines, but they can thicken a bit if you press harder. You can still get super delicate lines out of a pen or brush if you're skilled enough, Akihito Yoshitomi does a lot of detailed machine drawings with dip pens on YouTube if you're interested in watching someone ink in real time.
That's not to say nobody ever inks mainly with fineliners, and I think they were common in shoujo manga in the 2000s. They're very popular with people who draw anime-style illustrations on social media and can be very convenient to work with. They eventually worm their way into a lot of people's workflows, so there's no harm getting some experience with them now if you want to. I think with inking it's definitely a matter of trying a lot of things and seeing what suits you.
Whatever you end up with, I hope you have fun, Anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6447254
Honestly go for the one that appeals most to you. If price is a big factor any medium works well with a limited palette of 6 or more colors. There are many ways to make a certain medium more expensive and cheap, which is why I would also consider oil. For example, oil paint covers huge areas easily with very little paint and there are inexpensive oil painting papers to paint on. Another example is if you compare gouache and watercolor, the gouache paint is a little bit more expensive, because you will finish it faster, but on the other hand, you don't need good paper for gouache. All of them have their difficulties and advantages, but if I would recommend an all rounder that's forgiving I would suggest oil even though it's not in your list. If this is not an option for you, I would choose gouache over acrylic, because it's forgiving in brush quality and maintanence and it's better for sketching and making smaller pieces. The emulsion is not as strong as with acrylic, which makes it easier to handle the paint on the brush and canvas. Go for watercolor only if you love watercolor or you going to have a bad time. Watercolor is an outlier and has some specific qualities that you only should put up with if you really want to go for the watercolor look and feel. I agree that it's inexpensive to get into though, but it benefits from higher quality paper. So all in all, I would suggest gouache if you don't want to consider oil, but personally I don't like the Himi gouache, it has a strange consistency and it has too many colors. Consider a high quality brand like W&N, Holbein, Schmincke, Graham, but getting a small limited palette of 5-7 colors plus a big tube of white. Get those air tight wet palettes that everyone uses for gouache nowadays (I use them too, they are great) and you are good to go with a couple of synthetic taklon brushes. While you need thick paper to prevent buckling, you don't need 100% cotton, gouache is fine on cheap, thicker paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
on the subject of least expensive medium
technically, it would be using dry pigments mixed with gum arabic or egg yolk.
egg tempera is cheaper if you take a bit of the yolk from when you cook with eggs. a whole yolk is too much waste.
gum arabic is cheaper when you consider a bag of the dry powder can last for years upon years.
extra expenses are that egg tempera should be done on stiff support that is covered with traditional gesso ground which can be intimidating for a lot of beginners. i have tricks for anyone who actually cares to use it. watercolor paper can be more expensive if you don't have access to scrap wood. but if you don't egg or gum paint, then you can try out other media with the pigments.
for both, kolinsky is considered the best which can be quite expensive. but great thing for either is that they are not hard on the brushes unlike how oil can be and especially acrylic, and brush clean up is easier.

You will miss out on important additives and consistency enhancers if just using pigment and binder. It will be awful.

Get a good gouache set is my recommendation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450992
yes, i know most beginners would not be up for it. it depends how important expense is in the equation and how much intuition they have with materials. i know i wish i had gotten to it sooner.
egg tempera doesn't need to be mulled much if at all. the medium is pretty forgiving in proportions unless you're an absolute fuck-up like jazza.
watercolor on the other hand might benefit more from mulling, but can be stored in pans or little tubes. but i'll admit i mostly have experience with gum arabic paint for tinting drawings.
you don't have to just use binder and pigment. add honey, vinegar, oxgall, cloves, wine, opacifiers, extenders, if you want. i actually learned more about additives and preservatives from making my own paints. in particular oil paint has the most potential for being technical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450083
>>6450221
Hi Bridgman-san, you're doing fine, I've been posting along with you in /msg/ this past year. Attached is a page from when I was in the feet section, the memory drawing and corrections are both there, so it's great we both had the idea of correcting the drawing after the fact. The chapter I struggled the most on was the beginning chapter, with all the full figures, but once you start getting into the body parts it goes a lot quicker.

My end goal was to get my drawing EXACTLY like how Bridgman had it, but of course I often fell short. In the beginning, I would stare at the drawing for 15-20 minutes, drawing it in my head over and over again, then I would bang out the sketch really quickly, to not lose any information. When I was doing the full figures in the first chapter, I could only do 1-2 drawings at a time before my brain went caput, but it really does get a lot easier after that.

My one criticism of your process is to use pencil, and then ink on top. imo it's important to give yourself the room to make mistakes. Even all my ballpoint pen sketches I did from manga in /msg/, I used pencil underneath.

About me taking only 1 month to go through Bridgman versus how long you've been doing it, I just chalk that up to the fact that I already had several years of drawing experience before doing Bridgman, so I could do my studies very quickly, and i did it for 8 hours a day, like a maniac. For you, don't worry about how long you're taking, 1-2 hrs a day is plenty to progress. I think you're doing it right, I might've rushed Bridgman, to my own detriment.

Anyways, do your 30 mins of gestures, and your Bridgman, and you'll do fine. However, Bridgman isn't the end, even after finishing it I still feel inadequate. You really will have to study for the rest of your life.

>>6453639
I like to hold a pen or pencil in between my fingers, and press them onto paper in order to transfer ink or graphite onto the paper. I move my hand while still pressing down to make lines. I look at the lines Bridgeman drew, and move my hand in a manner that would produce a line like his. Repeat for all the lines that make up one of his drawings. He has a handy guide on the order of these lines near the start of the book, but you can wing it.

>>6453917
the head section isn't bad, you have to know what his drawings are shorthand for. drawing as many heads in cubes as you can showing the planes is tremendous practice for drawing in perspective. he would commonly recommend that as a warmup for that at the art students league.

a lot of the diagrams are modeled after how master painters in the 1800s and before would think about anatomy. the only one i don't care for in your picture is the child but that's making a point of what all the bumps are that cause plane changes on a face which you might not recognize as being indicative of the anatomy.

Imagine being covered in sharp spines.

You snag on things,you have to watch what you do extra carefully. You can't touch anyone else, or you can hurt them. But you have so much love in your heart that you could hug the whole world. But although he feels accursed, he's wrong. He can hug,but all he need do is take it slowly and he too can feel the affection that we all long for. Fiction makes life and people more interesting than it really is. The only people I would find interesting are the 1% of people, but even then I can't be friends with interesting people as I only see socializing as a way to gain something out of it for my stories. When I start to really get to know someone I start to think I'm wasting my time and my life is unfulfilled, it only feels fulfilled when I write my stories. Fiction lets me cope with my boredom as I can create the most fantastical worlds and build off of pre-existing cultures, concepts, history, philosophy, legends, and make them more intriguing in my eyes. It's like an endless playground for me. I think it's because the real world is not romantic enough for me, I like stories of epic battles, glory, strange things, and the exotic. The real world is very interesting in that it is spiritual and mystical with strange tales to tell, but real people are not interesting. I build off what I find interesting in the real world, and make it even more fascinating or perfect in my eyes. If I don't write about my OCs I feel like I'm going to die while being around friends or makes me feel more unfulfilled. It's most likely because I am over privileged so I find life and socializing boring because boredom in itself is a luxury.

Why you should not trust youtube shills:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Twy5Wo8m284

If you have any additional questions, ask them.
Remember to ignore all chinese shills.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6448815
>What is the most important thing to focus on making a successful illustration for a book cover?
A very strong focal point
>Also is it common for the artists making typography for the title?
No, but really that depends on the publisher and the book. You can see it for yourself -- take your favorite book and flip open to the first few pages, which usually have some disclaimers and copyright info. On those pages you'll often see two credits: one for the artist and one for the DESIGNER, who handles the typography and graphic elements. Sometimes the designer will be credited at the end, or on the flaps of the dust jacket.

>>6427259
>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6448961
Wittgenstein is /deep/ so it's hard to get all the nuances right, but I think the simplest explanation is his rope simile. There is not a single fiber that runs through the whole rope, the rope gains its strength from shorter individual fibers that share some overlap.
But if that seems like an inadequate explanation, it's because it is. Wittgenstein is notoriously hard to summarize, just like it's hard to summarize what makes anime anime. An important thread that runs through his later work is that 1)meaning is use and 2)meanings are fuzzy.
On that note, one last simile for the road. Just like we can play tennis even though it's not defined how high the ball can go, we can play what Wittgenstein terms a language game without working with what would essentially be a scientific level of clarity.

>>6449274
Late Wittgenstein isn't really deep; it just cuts through a lot of the autistic analytic philosophy of language that was common at the time and that was essentially all based on faulty intuition and prior tradition which was in turn based on faulty intuition. All of this stuff is basic intro-to-linguistics nowadays. The tl;dr is that a family can be identified as a family despite not necessarily all sharing any single feature because there's a relatively higher degree of commonality between elements within them than with elements outside of them and we're able to recognise that implicitly and point it out using language.

posts.com: Does anyone else feel like being a renderfag halted their progress? I had to go through a year without painting any of my drawings, instead focusing solely on the underdrawing and inks as much as possible. I found that I had neglected my perspective and value fundamentals for the sake of polished turds. On a positive note I learned to love inking/lineart and find it very enjoyable. I'm slowly returning to painting, just wondering if anyone has experienced a similar phenomenon.

yeah, i also was much better at rendering than at anything else.

i've spent the last few months forcing myself not to render anything, and instead just draw with lines, getting better at gesture drawing, perspective, etc. I also learned the importance of using "shapes", like what Frazetta used, which is something that I used to consider made up bullshit.

i can't wait to go back to rendering though, i can feel that what i've learned plus my rendering could produce interesting results

>>6435612
For me it wasn't any particular artist but learning just how important it was to see and think with a pencil and ink. I do a lot of thumbnailing in black and white now, so I'll let the shadow shapes guide me as to what should be drawn. I was looking at a Jungle Book art book so that's where served as inspiration for this piece. I do a lot of erasing and let random paint strokes from the positive and negative shapes create new ideas, so sometimes the final image doesn't always come out as planned.

>>6437972
I don't use Twitter or anything like that, I don't even remember how I found Gloss but I do remember that I liked his art immediately.
His construction and foreshortening is rock solid, his anatomy is on point, his figures are dynamic and expressive, his composition is impactful, and his rendering looks really nice on top of all of that. Not to mention that he has a fairly broad range, stylistically. If you check out his visual novel project Sweet Canvas you'll notice that the way that he paints his characters' faces ranges from super abstracted (like Kanna, who's my favorite desu) to more defined and "realistic" (like Io, for instance). I really would have to disagree with his art being "uninspired", Gloss is SOVL as fvck.

posts.com:
This is my OC Mimi and her cat Nico.

Nico is a species of cat that can't digest food on its own and instead ejects its intestines out of its mouth and down Mimi's throat to absorb the halfway digested nutrients from Mimi's stomach.
It's intestines release a chemical that makes Mimi feel happy and satiated making this a symbiotic relationship between the two. Because Mimi doesn't have many friends Nico's companionship and the chemicals it provides her is enough to let her live a happy life.

Mimi is just in a hospital gown for now but she wears anything she finds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6447084
Very cute! Thank you so much anon.
I really love the intelligence and creativity behind the box, at first it was lost on me, but then I realized this is actually a reference to schrodinger's cat, the often cited example for quantum mechanics wherein a cat inside a box can be either alive or dead and exists in a superposition between the two until someone is able to observe it which snaps it into one of the two states.
Naturally this is usually applied to cats and not girls, so the subversion by having Mimi in the box as opposed to Nico parallels their relationship as well, as cats are normally the pets of humans in charge, because of Mimi's reliance on Nico, Nico is the one that is often perceived to be in charge, which in turn is represented by Mimi being the cat inside the box, a beautiful subversion of the commonly known theory.

I also recognize as a cardboard box this is likely riffing off of Hideo Kojima-san, inventor of the stealth genre as he popularized and invented the use of cardboard boxes in his hit series metal gear solid. The cardboard box naturally evokes feelings of stealth due to this genre defining game, and in the words of Hideo Kojima himself
>When I first invented the stealth genre, I landed on cardboard boxes to act as stealth. Because of their innocent nature and ability to hide counterfeit goods under the guise of normal items people will see them as basic foundations of the world and overlook them. This is really where the strand-gameplay was first born
The cardboard box being a innocent item in society is a metaphor to the seemingly innocent nature of both Mimi and Nico, where people see them and only perceive them as an innocent young girl and her cute cat, but secretly they harbor a darkness within them that's hidden away from the world around them.

Overall I think this is a brilliant drawing that perfectly captures the deeper themes of my OCs in such a perfectly succinct manner.

Do you have an OC you'd like drawn?

>How is pc98 art made?
Artists would first draw the image on a physical piece of paper.
The paper would be scanned through a contemporary scanner.
After that, imperfections would be fixed and artists could begin with color and shading.
>is it possible to replicate with modern hardware?
Yes.
There are plenty of "pixelator" filters in modern software that can give you a good template.
Use a 16-color palette to block in your colors, then for rendering apply your dithering knowledge using specialized pixel art brushes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6439215
Several years ago I was very interested in this type of art. PC-98 games typically run at 640x400 resolution with 16 colors (although in practice there are often only 15 colors because one is indexed as transparent). There are actually rules as to which color values can be used, but there's no need to be so hardcore because the color choices are *practically* unlimited and nobody would be able to tell whether or not your colors would truly be possible on a PC-98 without analyzing the RGB values for each one.
There isn't one way these images were made. some artists sketched line art on paper, scanned, touched up and colored in a paint app. Some drew their lines directly in the paint app. What's needed from the paint app is:
1. Indexed painting mode, which assigns each pixel in your image to an index of your palette. If you change the color at that index, all the pixels in the image assigned to that index also change color.
2. Dithering tools. At a bare minimum, you need the ability to paint and fill using different patterns. Usually the standard dithering patterns are included but you can also create your own (helpful for doing textures, etc.). Some apps let you create custom gradients from your palette and automatically have dithering applied between each color.
Probably the two best Windows apps for doing this type of art are ProMotion and GrafX2. ProMotion is sort of the pixel art equivalent of Photoshop, as in being feature-rich and "industry standard" among serious pixel artists. It has everything you need, but can be overwhelming to use because of all the stuff you might not need. GrafX2 is simple and lightweight (and FREE) but its interface is a holdover from the 1990s and lacks some of the quality-of-life features people nowadays are used to having in their software. Both of these programs are based on Deluxe Paint 2, a very different paradigm from Photoshop that will take some getting used to if that's your frame of reference.

posts.com:
I remember I saw some pc98 threads on /v/ and was inspired so I spent a few hours finding all the files and got multipaint working but my my tablet wasn't working properly so I drew something with a mouse. If you wanted to draw pc98 art I would just recommend using whatever drawing program you like, look up the limitations and stick by them in your program of choice. The era appropriate multipaint has no layers, I think saving images is a bit cooked due to the emulator, tablets don't work properly, the UI is way worse than what you have now. The only thing it had going for it was the dithering brush and I'm assuming most modern programs will have something similar.
Basically if you want to do some "experimental history" you can try and get it all working but it also comes with the authentic frustration of using old computers, if you want to draw in that style just use a modern program, limit the resolution to 640x400 and use full black, full white, and only 16 other colours.
https://twitter.com/PC98_bot I'm sure there are also other places to find images made on the pc98

>>6396806
Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. You can get similar results blocking in color on a higher layer then using a soft eraser, but a good airbrush will do that all on its own. Imo, it’s an essential tool for ani semi-realistic soft shading.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

Previous Thread: boards.4chan.org/ic/thread/6448971

>>6451517
Don't worry about how many hours you're putting in, just focus on making sure that any time in general is just being utilised well. Deconstruct, observe, and copy. The biggest part of drawing to begin with will be learning shapes and anatomy. Which means that figure drawing should be anyone's focus. No need to perfect shading, but look into the ways in which people use gesture and shapes to construct the body in different poses.

The more you draw poses, the better it'll be for you when it comes to drawing the things you want, because the foundations will be there. If you don't know how to draw the things you want, you will likely fail and give up. So accept that itll take time and your drawings will be shit at first, but understand that you're building a visual library to pull from later. So:

>learn 3d shapes
>learn anatomy and how 3d shapes build the human body
>find figure references and copy them
Take as much time as you need, and feel free to focus on specific parts of the body at a time. You'll likely learn shapes before gesture, so your figure drawings will likely be messy and very blocky/robotic. As you understand more anatomy you'll begin to remember where muscles go and how the lines fold and bend around them, and that'll likely come after learning the general shapes.

Pretty much what I'd say to any beginner. I've seen that many start off trying to do too many things at once and then sort of panic and give up. One of the most important aspects of learning anything is to accept that you will be shit for a while, and to remind yourself that being shit and practicing is how you improve, because eventually you'll ask yourself why something is shit and seek answers.

That's totally normal anon. Hairy/scratchy/chicken scratch lines are really common when people first start drawing.
It's their brains saying "I know the line goes here somewhere, but I'm not sure exactly where"
The more you draw the more understanding, confidence and certainty you'll have, and it will show in your lines.
Art isn't a talent, it's a skill. Anyone can go to the gym and get big muscles and anyone can draw and get good at art.
It's just up to you if you actually want to do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451914
>is it intentional to draw the light/shadow mapping areas with hard edges? it makes it very distinct but i am not sure if its beg mistake or design choice
Yeah, it's intentional. It's both a style and a learning choice. The aim is to get across the idea with fewer values and strong lines, no infinite rendering polishing, I think it looks cool and I'd also say it's a good exercise to go and outright define the shadow areas with hard lines then fill them in so as to teach me how to quickly do just that, see and represent values and shadows in a way that pops. And I really just like how it looks but to be truthful, I'm also not good enough at rendering "realistically" like >>6451685 so this way it looks better I think. I would like to learn both of course.

Amazing website idk if that was intentional but I love the look, feels like something one'd find on old internet, very nice.


>>6451889

>>6452519
Thank you sir very much.
Nice, I like the vibe of your picture. I think it would do a lot if your linework had somewhat more naturally-varying levels of thickness instead of being uniformly thick throughout the whole stroke. If you look at your reference, there are also many lines and areas that are somewhat "messy" but since the line thickness is organic it adds to the whole image. Basically I think you should focus less on making "perfect" linework and more on giving it that kind of "whip" that makes the whole image come alive, but idk if that's how it's even done in manga panels and my linework is probably also shit so idk haha.

>James Gurney: Imaginative Realism: How to Paint What Doesn't Exist
>Francis Tsai: 100 Ways to Create Fantasy Figures

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428274
Just got this, extremely disappointing compared to the color & light book.
I feel like color & light offered a well rounded balance of theory, technical information and examples that other books lack and is exhaustive.

The composition and narrative book is a by-the-numbers text dump of golden ratio, rule of thirds, dark foreground, light background type stuff and offers no examples from Greg Rutkowski himself via thumbnails/sketches or other studies to show practical examples.

Framed Ink 1 & 2, Creative Illustration by Loomis and Edgar Paynes composition of outdoor painting all offer much more.

3DTotal back to their usual low quality books.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435278
You can learn anatomy in med school, but you still won't be able to draw it well. Figure drawing is learning to draw the figure. Learning anatomy is purelly informational knowledge. It does help you understand what you are trying to represent, or when drawing from imagination to know where to position things, but it isn't drawing information. Most pepole say you should start with figure drawing, when you feel confortable with it but you feel you are being held back by not knowing the specifics of the muscles and body parts, then you go to anatomy.

>>6444668
anon, i've gone through a thousand (literally) artbooks and his books are LITERALLY the only ones that a beginner can actually use
everything else is requires someone else who is better at drawing than you to go through the book with you to teach you what is garbage information, what to ignore, etc.

one case in particular, Marshall Vandruff mentioned that the How to Draw book by Scott Robertson is really great in the first half but absolutely garbage in the second half
stuff like this is a common occurrence with artbooks so if you're an actual lbeginner, I'd say ignore everything else and stick with this guy's books until you know a little more about drawing to be able to filter out the garbage from other books

As somebody who owns a signed copy, this is one of the few top tier art books worth getting. It actually goes into detail about recreating the style they created for the movie so it’s more than just a collection of finished paintings and renders. I’m sure it’ll be scanned eventually, but definitely something worth grabbing in case it gets rare in my opinion. About my only gripe is that Diane barely has any art in the book compared to the other characters, and there aren’t a lot of shorthand sketches of their final designs. Still, probably the best artbook I own.

>>6445156
>Semi exposed breasts where you'd clearly see the areola, but for some reason it's not there
Areolas vary in size, some of them can have a large radius.
>Artist work is amazing, he vanishes from the face of the earth
I in no way want to imply I'm amazing, but I formed a decent following in the short time I posted with a pseudonym.
In my experience, as a young man, I started to cringe to the things I drew and got me a piece of the internet's attention. I found out that this wasn't a part of me that I wanted to keep developing, I couldn't be proud of the things I did. I mean, would you show the anime girl with 10k likes on twitter to your mother? With a straight face? Would you present yourself with a lady saying you are an "anime artist"? I concluded that it was a distraction that would lead me nowhere except meeting geeks and weirdos.
I think the same thing applies to some of the so called nsfw artists that are somewhat competent at their craft, even more if they are young (18-24) and still are figuring out who they want to be and what path they want to choose, what ideal of a man they strive to become.
The only positives I got from doing this online art thing was the fact that I could buy any collectible figure I wanted at any time, I just needed to open a commission slot for whatever the figure price was and that was it, not much to be proud of. The acquaintances I met? Long far gone since I yanked everything. The experiences I had online? Time wasted in my opinion.

Can't see anyone on his mid 40's drawing anime girls for a living and not being miserable, conscious of it or not. Maybe most of those artists in your mind came to the same conclusion and that's why they vanished.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6452974
I can only speak from USAF experience, but I've been an artist since before I joined so I've got a good view of it.

In basic training it'll be hard to get any hobbies done, but that's just about a 2 month period so it's not too bad. It's easy enough to just doodle in a sketchbook or something, which was what primarily got me through it.

After that when you get to your actual job it isn't too bad. There are some jobs where you're constantly working with your hands and doing gruntwork, like airfield maintenance and various CE jobs, but others like anything cyber you can pretty easily just sit around and do a ticket a day, and call it good from there, doodling the rest of your time. As long as you're not in an intel job or working in a high security area, you could even bring your ipad to work as long as your supervisor doesn't have an issue with it.

The real issue with the military in my experience is just the culture. It's obviously very authoritarian, but the military will also try to get more out of you than you might wanna put in. In the Air Force at least, it is expected that you will do volunteering both on and off duty, that you will progress your education and certifications, and that you won't complain if you're told you're gonna waste your own personal time on some vanity project the commander has going.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6453072
Beyond that, though, yeah the military is a perfectly fine choice. Make sure your recruiter doesn't yank you around or screw you. I know a guy with a master's degree in computer science who ended up Security Forces (cops/infantry, basically) because his recruiter didn't give a fuck.

You'd be surprised how many artists were military, though. Guweiz is my favorite example, since he literally just did his two mandatory years and during that period did all the grinding needed to reach a decent level. If you're dedicated and good at finessing the system, it can honestly be perfect.

>>6452974
I enlisted in the USAF and got my STEM degree paid for and still have an intact GI bill. I saved a lot while in and racked up to like 400k in net worth at one time with savings + investment growth before the economy went to shit. I joined to become a better writer and artist. Vast majority of the cool artists and writers I admired were one form of military or another, so I was like "I am putting myself through that". I wanted from the military whatever it gave these other artists, and these artists weren't a bunch of faggots tucked away in some ivory tower circlejerking each other off, they were living a life and drawing their inspiration from real life experience.

I have zero regrets, and I think as an artist it was one of the best decisions I've ever made. I am glad I trusted my gut. I don't know about other branches but for USAF, I had plenty of time to draw, and I actually drew more because I was less depressed while serving than during civilian life. You can definitely carry a sketchbook or an iPad around even while deployed. I did commissions while deployed in the middle east and made phone calls via a texting app. I am proud of my service and love being in shape, I am glad I am not some NEET skinnyfat or a lardass who only dreams of being in shape.

Your experience might be different though. I liked the military lifestyle, culture, and community, while others seem to hate it. Maybe I had a good time because it was the Air Force and maybe the other branches are super shitty, but then during my time in the Air Force plenty of people were still bitching anyway. People are always gonna bitch. People warned me about the Air Force too before I joined. Whatever. You don't know if you're going to like something until you actually do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6453498
Study animation, western or Japanese. They both teach techniques for maintaining character consistency, after all it's key to what they do. Practice drawing characters using character sheets (for anime, settei); here's a useful site: https://setteidreams.net/settei/

It is tough work, but to draw a character sheet you really do need to pay closely attention in keeping things in proportion with each other and often things like rulers are used in order to do so. Ear heights should stay in the same location relative to the other features of the head; eye shapes (the whole shape as well as the inner shapes) should stay very similar in size and shape (here in your drawing you have strong "sanpaku" eyes in one drawing but not the other, in other words, the iris takes up more space on one of the characters compared to the other. Eyes are crucial to character likeness, so you will get a lot of value from being more exact with the eye shape you draw. Brow thickness is also a very important thing to keep consistent. If you look at any settei, you will see just how exact they do it.

But that is settei though, and outside of that, it's okay to not draw so precisely.

For your level and experience, I would say this problem is fairly normal though. Consistency also means stability and robustness of your mental models. Your mental models are things like how you draw things, how you think about the different patterns you draw. It contains 3D and 2D information. Since there is a lot of freedom to stylized art, your mental models are probably still pretty loose in many areas. Pursue artistic growth in general and it will improve. Make sure to make some art with your best shot. Only engaging with art with the desire to practice and make improvements will hold you back when it comes to actually doing the art thing.

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.
------
>Community Resources
>Tag the OP if you want a resource included here.

This thread gave me all I needed to know about this board. It's full of people with no talent or abstractist thinking who spend years and years trying to fit into being an artist, Or Illustrator or anything. They work hard or work for a long time to become this thing they want to be however because of this they become cynical, jaded, Do they truly love it? Are they creators, Artists or just people who can draw very well.
They spend a lot of money and time on the BEST NEW equipment thinking it will make them better and it does produce a better product but at the end of the day, there are two realms when it comes to professions like these (To put it simply, Call them abstract and then traditional) and one needs to respect the other whichever they reside in
It's much like /mu/ when you post music.
Your art is awesome OP, whoever this is. The use of white is incredibily impressive . I'm always interested in art that needs to be closely looked at and when I draw, sometimes I try to draw something that is a bit "tricky" to discern what it truly is, Opening the work to multiple interpretations other than the artists.

>>6453196
Well anon for a real answer it has a lot of qualities that are attractive and at least worth talking about.

Balance, contrast, rhythm, focal points. These things exist in most representational art, but here they exist kind of by themselves, deconstructed.

Lines, curves, shapes in representational drawing are tools, means to an end. Here they are the subject, the focus.

You can see how in some spots, even two lines create the suggestion of 3d space, not any real space mind you, but a sort of abstraction of 3d space itself.

You can see how colored shapes interact almost like they are transparent stained glass. Not necessarily following the actual color theory rules of how they'd interact, but still reading as color interactions of that sort.

It's like molecular/deconstructed cuisine. A way of treating the ingredients in a different way, of letting them take a life of their own.

It's not. While I'm not autistic, I do have an autistic obsession with detail, and one of the things I always struggled with when learning to draw animu shit was figuring out how the chin was supposed to look when drawn from a lower angle, and how it connects to the neck/throat, because so many animu artists ignore it or just flat out don't know how to draw it. In the same vein, a lot of animu artists rely on side-mouth, despite the fact that it looks horrid, and serves as no shortcut if you know how to draw a proper mouth from the side. It's just a flaw that somehow turned into an excuse for style.
If you look at 3D models of anime characters, some Japs have made a career out of cheating a 2D look out of a 3D model, by making everything move independent of reality, which speaks volumes about how some anime styles just make no sense.
As an aside, don't take my criticism as a personal attack. It's nice to have a civil discussion in this shithole for once.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6442749
virtually nobody draws the actual eyeball and you probably don’t either
eyeballs are really, really fucking small relative to visible eye structures, which in combination with the convex iris taking up so much of the frontal plane leads to the extreme dynamism of the eye
in contrast, anime eyeballs, if approached as such, would be absolutely massive relative to the visible eye, to the point that they would be clipping each other and the skull in order to achieve the relative flatness of the visible structure
what 90% of people, and all the examples posted itt, do is draw a circle roughly lining up to one eyelid in whatever perspective and considering that an eyeball, when in reality they’re drawing a simplified ocular cavity and drawing the eyelid along one edge and ad libbing the other, which is why the perspective makes no sense and why it looks so flat and symbol drawn despite supposedly being constructed, it’s just marking off where to curve the eyelid on the frontal plane of the face with extra steps

which is fine, because the typical anime eye is not spherical and doesn’t condone an actual eyeball, it’s a flattened stylisation of the surface structure of the eye
yes, there’s a degree of 3d structure to it, and yes there’s a degree of anatomical foundation to it, but it’s a flattened surface structure
people are told to learn about real eyes so they can manipulate that understanding of the surface structure of the eye into an anime stylisation of it, but retards hear this and think it means they’re to be approached the same way

>>6435807
A high likes-to-views percentage is not necessarily good, because it may indicate too many likes, or too few views.
Too many likes relative to views may mean that most of your interactions are with friends and family (you're in a circlejerk), or you are in a very insular fandom with little outside reach. Too few views relative to likes may mean your reach is being limited artificially (you're shadowbanned), or you're not being retweeted enough, or your circle of retweeters aren't popular enough to generate views for you.
Looking at most of the big (50k+) art accounts I follow, the likes-to-views ratio tend to be between 2% to 7%, with most hovering at 3%~4%

>>6435657
The barrier to entry in art is high if you didn't start young. When you're young, you aren't as hard on yourself and are more likely to be pleased with your results even if they look like shit, and just through repetition and time you'll reach a somewhat adequate level. If you reach a point where you can produce works that are at least halfway to your liking, it's much easier to grind fundamentals through dedicated practice since you have some existing grasp to apply it all to and enjoy the results of your improvement. If you're starting in your twenties or older with the drawing capacity of an 8 year old, grinding basics can feel like a complete waste, since you're basically building from a true zero, unable to produce anything that you're even partway pleased with, and your "fun time" drawings will tend to continue to look like shit for quite a while.

It's like why an active construction worker will have a much easier (and more enjoyable) time when taking up formal weightlifting than will an obese couch potato who has to "grind" basic shit like standing for more than five minutes and doing exercises with 5 pound dumbbells.

>>6436845
This isn't a comment I got but these 2 characters I've been fleshing out for a comic for years, ended up getting "copied" by 2 big name cartoon shows like 4 years after I imagined them myself. It pissed me off at first, but I didn't let it get to me. I resolved instead to adjust my characters and their narrative world in a way that mogs those cartoons(in my opinion,) and makes my characters even more distinctly my own. I'll never get famous from it and retards might still try to compare my characters (which came first) to the characters from the cartoons, or even some unpredictable media I've never heard of. But I'll never doubt myself about it and that's what matters. My creations have a life of their own, it's my job to convince people to see them as distinct, and hell it might even be fun to lean into some of the comparisons for laughs. If you aren't fighting tooth and nail to carve out your own identity through your creations you're just too weak.

>>6439229
lol i'm a person who says this sometimes (paired with other advice). i don't say "looks like shit" because it's just not a useful citicism
it doesn't tell the other person what they did wrong or how to improve on the picture or which skill they should focus on
furthermore, it's not like putting a lot of effort into a shitty image has never happened to me - i assume the other person already knows their work looks "bad somehow" but doesn't know how to fix it, and that in that state it's pretty easy to fall into the trap of thinking all the time you put into something was a total waste and a sign that you have hit a "wall" and will never improve.
so, in combination with other suggested practical solutions, it's just a reminder that time invested into practice isn't useless, at a time when it is easy to think that way, and have that mentality block your growth.
