If you don't like critiques you're free not post anything, I don't go around insulting anons for their work, I pinpoint the glaring problems and direct them to good sources to learn from while giving some practice advice, it's always something they can easily do, not some obscure concept. posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

You mean David Finch? The extra girth makes it easier to hold in general. You can hold it with a more relaxed grip or since it is soft, grip it tight without much strain on your hand. This helps to ease cramping from long sessions. It also makes it a bit easier to control of the tip of the pencil.

if you haven't tried the memorization technique, now would be a good time to try it, especially if you're going for simpler studies like for the features.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

This will really help the shapes you are studying in Morpho come out in your imaginative drawing

>>6378026
I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6385906
I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

i got a question
does a master study need to be a 1:1 copy of the subject?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6427376
It feels really pedantic at first but you need be able to copy things exactly. When other artists do something successfully, the copying skill will let you figure out how to do it for yourself, so it unlocks a lot of learning to be able to do it right. You are already starting to get the even more important thing though, which is that exact copying forces you to develop your ability to see.

>>6431161
Oh it just looks sort of blocky like the Bridgman figures. You have the right idea in schematizing the block in but it needs to be a little more accurate. The values also look like they're done visually despite the planarization, so the dimensionality gets reduced. Speaking of values, this is a total pain but you should try to clean them up more. Literally sharpen your pencil to the finest point you can and fill in the little white dots on the paper, then go in with a kneaded eraser and pick out all the spots that are too dark. It'll be a huge pain in the ass but it will make your shadows especially look way flatter and give much more the illusion of depth, reality, and completeness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450840
>drawabox
No wonder drawing makes you feel like ass. I can't imagine doing that crap and I've been drawing for years. I don't know if it'll help but I'll lend you some of my advice. Pick your favorite artist you want to draw like and start copying their stuff. Not serious 1:1 studies, just make some shitty doodles with whatever looks cool to you. In my case I just copied Akira panels because I always loved it. I must've copied half the series at some point. After a while I began to understand how Otomo drew figures. I didn't realize then that I was basically just doing figure studies, just not with irl people. Some time later I got confident enough to learn from other artists I admired and got better at copying, then I actually went over the fundies books that everyone pushes on prebegs. I felt like I learned in reverse but there is no wrong way to learning as long as you're making progress. Another piece of advice is to grow some skin and learn to take and LISTEN to advice from your superiors and apply it. Don't assume you know better when someone tells you this shading is inconsistent or this fold doesn't make sense etc.

Point is, while art is practice and hard work, it doesn't mean you can't have fun. Like with working out, you can make fun out of activities.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6453040
mathchad here, took a few art classes. Like anon said, it can be hit or miss.

I found the painting classes were bullshit "do whatever you want" with limited/no instruction. The drawing classes were more intense and actually had guided instruction, we mostly worked with charcoal but went into ink with brushes, printmaking with copper plates, and a few other things that I'm forgetting.
I put in about as much time with specifically that one drawing class as I did for the linear algebra course I was taking at the time. It was a very good class.
Just email the profs with what you'd like to get out of the class and see if it's a good fit, ask for their syllabus, and find out if it's more "free form" or more guided with higher expectations than just showing up and "relaxing"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Years ago, I got so fascinated with this one single artist (Luen Kulo) that it ruined my objectives when I was younger. I would study only his art, his lines, his proportions, color, line art. For me, the artist had (still think it has) the golden proportion anime/manga, perfect (for my personal taste). Nothing will ever top it, I could spend hours appreciating his drawings.

But I got so addicted to his art (I would print screen frames of his streams to have his sketches as well) that I started to lose the will to draw. It would never be like that, my lines. I eventually gave up drawing all together, because of this pitiful feeling of wanting to draw exactly like him.

Took me years, but I'm finally mature enough to just pursue the best I can do, so I started learning again, and it has being fun. Using different artists as reference is refreshing as well. Still love Luen though, but in a health way.

Anyone had similar experiences?

I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

I also post comics but those don't do very well in terms of numbers despite getting lots of positive comments and stuff.

How did you guys break through the limit? Is the solution really just to keep drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

I'm stuck at 230 or so but I only do original stuff mostly. Try doing fanart or drawing bigger account OCs. The only reason I am at 230 and not 30 is because I did art for someone's OC I like and they RT'd it. But do it only if you like their art otherwise it's scummy imo.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6451767
I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

The Mona Lisa is a portrait of a woman after childbirth. During the Renaissance, children were believed to be conceived by god rather than the woman baring them. Leonardo, being the genius he was, understood much more about the female anatomy. If you look in pic related, it shows he understood the essential way that women's bodies are designed to create life, like how they regulate their body temperature to preserve the baby.
Leonardo is saying that women are an essential part of the perfect universe that was part of the Renaissance zeitgeist. The Mona Lisa is shown in a powerful straight on view and is connected with the otherworldly earthly background.
Thus, the Mona Lisa shows us that women's ability to give birth is one of the most magical things in this world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What exactly is the difference between an irl photo looking off and a drawing looking off?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6453184
An unmanipulated photo likely looks off from lens warp/distortion which is a consistent kind of distortion. A drawing is an inconsistent distortion that is essentially randomized depending on what the artist can or can't measure accurately. In a weird photo, say the entire outer edge is stretched unnaturally. In a drawing, you might have everything look accurate to life except the hand or nose or whatever. Camera lens distortion is one reason your front camera on a phone makes your nose look bigger than it is. The nose is closer to the lens than the rest of the face. But if someone drew you, your nose would look fine but they could randomly fuck up your left eye or something.

posts.com: Is it possible to make a living selling only graphic novels, just like a prose novelist would? I want to be a mangaka, but I don't want the pressures of weekly / biweekly / monthly serialization...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: only if you use ai to improve your workflow like modern authors do

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6452991
It’s possible to go balls deep in Maria Sharapova but what’s possible and what’s realistic are galaxies apart. That said, you probably have a better chance at the above than making a living on comic books, let alone getting one published by a reputable publisher. These are lessons we have to learn the hard way however. So go shill your comics, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6452991
It's possible. Authors obviously exist. But the reason why people do a monthly serialization is to make money. They supplement their process by selling the single issues monthly because waiting years until the project is done can definitely be costly and you can't make any money during that time.
Furthermore releasing the single issues also acts as advertising to customers each month since it will be along with other new releases. If you do a graphic novel you only get this once.
If you do want to though check out Image Comics. They have no requirement for any time of monthly output and you keep your intellectual property unlike a lot of other publishers.

https://imagecomics.com/submissions

Warning though you have A LOT of competition.

posts.com: if you're entering this with the primary intention of making money, you've already lost

>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas

because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)

posts.com:
Im not afraid of AI art. That doesnt mean I like it or support it. Its not really something for me. I prefer my own art drawn from me. Something from my cringey weeby soul. Something I can be proud of.

I was initially sad and was that my hopes of living off of commissions having been crushed. Even though it was a goal I had in the near future.
Then I realized I havent taken commissions in years because the last time my I was drawing art for the others, I got completely broke me to the point Im in retail hell. It took me years to recover. Now I draw for myself and I draw for fun and its been great! I feel bad for the artist's losing income over this, it sucks to get your pay cut and I know a lot of you barely get enough.
I feel like AI is like the cheap ass plastic decorations, people like pretty on the whim with no greater thought. But there will always be people who prefer fine craftsmanship over mass production.
I have a new direction with my art, whether it successes or fails, at least I did a life long dream.

>>6439986
"realism" is a catch-all term in modern context that can include anywhere from botticelli, raphael, rembrandt, rubens, caravagio, velazquez, greuze, david, "Realists" such as courbet, the academics, impressionists, sargent, norman rockwell, "American realists" and modern ateliers, photorealists, celeb prsmacolor speed draws, etc. i suppose when the kind of art that one aspires for and surrounds himself with are modernists or styles for cartoons and video games, these are all simply realism.
academic/atelier art is a more specific category of its own with emphasis on severe naturalism, with its own different unnamed styles within. something can even be very naturalistic, such as velazquez, yet when compared with works done under an atelier or academic setting and training, it is obvious they are different and it is clear which is which.
michelangelo never had to learn how to draw in the "stale academic study way" yet still produced works of genius.

NTA but that’s overwhelmingly a matter of most people don’t give a shit about barque plates and don’t put the time in to doing them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6447367
plenty of people can draw accurately (enough) without doing the bargue method, at a fraction of the time. if they apply the bargue method to check for accuracy, it wouldn't be too difficult to gain that extra bit of accuracy and naturalism, but they might feel it hampers their workflow and the extra amount of accuracy is not worth the extra time unless they are trying to completely capture likeness.
graphite and vine charcoal along with the method are quite forgivable.
i don't mean that drawing objectively necessarily requires very little skill, but it isn't a sure way of gauging skill between artists. a lot of the old masters did not attain the level of modern naturalism, but are still more skilled generally.

I think not having any expectations of making it or something along those lines makes comic making satisfying for me. I just learn so much from drawing comics and I think it has helped me build more character making me much more disciplined, resolute, and patient. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Do you really get better from "just drawing"? I could probably do that everyday but I don't think it'll help. It's the studying/mental effort that makes drawing difficult for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6445952
Yes and no. You won’t magically learn new skills by just drawing. But you’ll build up many of the required prerequisites to drawing like hand eye coordination, focus, understanding of the process, visual recognition, etc…
Theyre the time consuming skills that you can’t be taught by reading a book. And until you actually put in the physical time drawing and gain those skill you’ll be dogshit no matter how much you study or however many books you read.

Just drawing is an absolute necessity to gitting gud and it will improve your baseline abilities. But it won’t reach you new concepts by itself until you bother learning them.

>>6423332
Instead of taking a course, do the following every day for a week:

Write down a list of at least 5 things you like. Does not have to be only artists, can be media of any sort, or hell even odd shit like food if you want.

Make a venn diagram. Label it with one of the 5 subjects.
Write what you want to learn from the subject, artwise, in the middle
Write what you already can do as good or better than the subject in the left
Write what you don't like/care about the subject in the right.

Repeat for each of the daily 5.

---

It's an exercise for self-awareness and understanding your influences and where you want your directions to go. When you have done all these you can then use that knowledge to know what you wanna study from the different subjects. Character design is downstream from that stuff.

posts.com:
>>6446839
Here's the way the site works: when you try to load a video, the website launches an app on your computer for the video player. This is a proprietary player you need to install AND must be running at all times, otherwise the video stops playing. This software, while running (even if the site is closed), straight up blocks any kind of capture, even simple screenshots, which is annoying if you want to copy the photo the instructor is using as a ref, since they are generally not provided in the exercise files. On top of all that, the website puts your full name + user ID randomly somewhere on the screen over the video. It's not always there, pops in and out, and is on a random area of the video every time.

In short, there ARE a few ways to record the screen and get the video and bypass their player cockblocking you, but you'll still have a tiny watermark with your personal info randomly teleporting over the screen, which you'd have to manually cover in video editing, a pain in the ass, and also might end up blocking useful areas of the video, so it's really not worth it unless someone develops an addon to scrape the video directly off the site before the watermark is overlaid on top, and then somehow either also obtain the subtitles, or recreate them from scratch.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6449852
1/2
Was thinking about this just this morning. AI is definitely a wakeup call but certainly not the death of the artist. It has its place and use as a tool of convenience.

I think we'll have to adapt in much the same way that AI does. Specifically, by rejecting digital mediums for the physical, relearning traditional techniques, and developing a unique style after figuring out some fundies. Many art communities online are having absolute meltdowns because they can't tell the difference between an AI piece and an original work even though the funny shit is the vast majority of people online are using digital and tablets. There's a very simple workaround for this: make your art physically. Sure some pajeet can make a robot that can emulate skill, but no pajeet will replace the human soul. Trads don't have to give a shit, just post timestamp.

Personally, digital artwork lacks a lot of appeal in the first place. Not to say it isn't or can't be good, I just think it's missing something fundamental to the human soul that goes into it. The mistakes are too easily corrected, the physicality of touching paper, oils, color, spilling shit and just getting weird with it are gone. Spill coffee on your computer and you could lose a keyboard, spill coffee on a canvas and it can be inspiring. AI gives me the feeling people are seeing with their eyes whether or not a piece has appeal, and not their heart. Some of the dumbest shit speaks to me even if it's not some high ideal, but so far, AI hasn't. It simply doesn't have a human soul to connect with.

I'm predicting a renaissance of physical, traditional, and certainly original art soon as a natural counter to AI and looking forward to it. We'll end up with a lot of weird growing pains but I truly think it'll pay off. Once you can show something was made with your own hands, there can be no further doubt to authenticity. Mark my words, in the coming years a selling point to media will be a "all human art team."

>How do they choke out the words "I spent the last ten years drawing shitty pictures"
I think this is the core of the problem.
When you are a kid, you don't spend time thinking about stuff like "Does this angle look right?" "I can't fucking draw hands!" "these colors suck"
No. Kids draw because it is fun. When I was a kid, I drew the map of Paper Mario because I wanted to do it and it was the most soulful shit. When you're an adult however, things are different. You are now able to look at your drawings and see the technical "flaws". This is why it's so hard for older people to get into drawing, your taste has matured while your skill stayed the same.
OP, there is NOTHING wrong with pumping out shitty drawings. I know it's easy to say, and looking at my own beg shit fucking hurts. I feel you. But again, this is completely normal. Compared to other adults your age, you are trying. And I think that is something very humble.

I’m old. Mid thirties. I made a book of drawings for everyone for Christmas. I spent about a month making content for it. My family has been asking me what I have been doing for the past few years and I always say drawing, but I never show them. So I finally put together a loose story, made some illustrations, had them printed into books and I gifted them to the immediate family. 8 books were sent out. Nobody really said anything. They just said “thanks for the Christmas gifts”

At least I didn’t have to spend a lot of money on presents. Even so the books for like $40 each to make and ship out. So maybe that’s a lot.

If you are looking for validation at an late age, you won’t find it from drawing. Do it for yourself. Do it now, so that when you are 40 you won’t wish you had started when you were 30. Also think of it this way. A 15 year old has really only spent 10yrs drawing so you can easily surpass him by 40.

Started when I was 28. Worked for the industry by 33. I'm now hitting 35. It's not THAT hard but very time consuming. Need to give up everything for it. Luckily it's easy to keep up with art trends thanks to social media and even things like twitch.
Just focus on your studies, create your own shit, see why your favorite art looks cool to you. Try to MIMIC them (not copy, or sometimes copy, I dunno copying never felt like I learned anything unless it was from Old Masters), be self aware of your own mistakes, and keep drawing. As long as you draw things YOU want to do, you'll continue to enjoy it.

>>6443047
I took online courses much later, but the courses were only disappointing as they seem to only teach Their methods of what the studies were (which can easily be found here through Bridgman, Loomis, Vilppu, etc).
First two years was me trying to copy and understand basic shapes and Bargue Drawing Course. Did Vilppu, it didn't make sense to me. Followed Hampton, then went back to Vilppu now I can't get enough of his teachings. Sometimes the studies felt pointless, but the more personal drawings I did, the more it made sense Why the studies were important. This is why a balance is good.
When I took an online course much later in my journey, I was disappointed because I got little feedback and was simply told I was doing everything "correctly". Frustrated, I started looking towards discord communities for animation or drawing friends. I eventually stumble onto the right people when showing my work, and lead me into a job. So it's very possible as long as you do well with your drawings, and share it to the right people, you can get there.

It honestly makes me kinda sad when older people are unhappy like this. Not that you're old (you still have a whole unlived life ahead of you), but its from my 20yo perspective. Get your shit together, old man! My best advice if you care enough to take it is to just draw anyway. Life is too short to care what others think. Enjoy the act of creating just for the sake of creating or you'll inevitably fall off. Its like exercise, you need to be consistent and fall in love with the work in order to get to an advanced level you dream of getting to. Every good artist I've met that was advanced in skill had gotten that far because art had been cemented in their life as an escape, as a form of entertainment or therapy. If you don't want to fail, you have to indulge yourself in art, soak in it, go through cringe phases, and let yourself be cringe and bad because that's how you grow. Good luck OP, I hope you learn to accept the parts of yourself you're embarrassed of. Its hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I am 57,and will be 58 soon enough. I stock shelves at night and have a long commute,so I have ed limited time to draw. So I am now telling the whole story of this ancient forbear that I did as an experiment, but aimed my time at doing stories on standardized comic book sized Bristol board, then using scanned bits,I would assemble a 2d sculpture effect comic panels that were of the standardized size. Now,realizing that I owe it to the Universe to crank out as many stories as I can. So,I am just filling up a sketchbook with this story,and I proceed foward,adding details as I make up the story and exploring images and leaping blind in creating the definitive imagery that might be the only source material that I can present. I just want to see where it goes. I did this for 180 strips of another story that was ballpoint pens,and sketchbooks in waiting rooms.I had a webcomic for 10 years, but Covid ate it,financially beggering me,and having the domain name gobbled up by China. I didn't draw for two years,crippled by depression and despondent of ever even trying again. But marijuana entered the scene,and suddenly I want to CREATE. Stories,sketches,I refused to hinder my Whimsy nor structure my projects. Even this story is taking interesting turns. I had to create the look of a character that only existed before as a random sketch in a sketchbook,so I reimagined him,and invented him on the spot. He is the Prince,awkward, adolescent, unsure. I introduced him with a bunch of squiggles that suggested elaborate court costumes, and when I was drawing a full sized rendering of him,I referred to the squiggles as I designed the clothes. When I was doing the other Snowglobe comic,I would take the time to design important things, but now,I am just plunging foward. I now consider my art style as one of a writer with an artistic bent,trying to tell stories in trying circumstances.

Now...I am fighting the clock. Smoke and draw. Smoke and draw. What goes on the paper is Canon.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6450975
Stories come from anywhere.

This was the very first strip I made. I was resigned to haunting waiting rooms with my girlfriend to be supportive and such,so I brought a sketchbook and the demon head was the first thing that I drew,and even that was a random bunch of squiggles. Then I thought about why the demon head was there,and drew another character next to it. This was more planned, I deciding to have this person a blend of two other characters as if they had a baby. And soon a story was materializing under my pen. I would often make single page snapshots of stories in progress, stuffing them with enough suggestive details to make the reader supply their own conclusions about what was going on. But the second strip had another character, and I made her a younger sister to be J's age,and a personality evolved from a few word balloons. The Art influences the Story and the Story influences the Art.

It can be too easy to want to fill up every spot with something, but then with every spot a "point of interest" the whole thing becomes devalued in a way.

posts.com:
>>6451329
I see. I am not sure know how to help you after that. it comes down to how much detail is too much and how much is fine. On the process while we work it tends to happen that as we get tired our attention naturally starts to get narrower and narrower and and focus on smaller and smaller area of the picture where we tend to cram more and more of those "cool shiny details." But we loose focus on the big picture and it comes out awkward with one small area of the picture being detailed but almost totally disconnected from the rest.

I can only guess this might have happened with your process and the eyes on. >>6451226

This is nothing special just normal attention fatigue. The best way combat this is to take breaks more frequently and allow the mind to rest itself, just a few minutes is okay. And then when you come back look at the picture from a far view to see it as it is fully. This is even done in traditional art classes when you put your picture down to the wall and need to look at it from far away to get a fresh look

Since you do digital you can also use digital methods like flipping the canvas left-right periodically or zooming out and then back or temporarily turning the picture to greyscale etc. The main goal is to break looking at the very same thing for long time period and give the mind a break or a new perspective.

>>6411492
Depends on where you’re at, skill-wise and what your goals are. But in order from when I started to now, some books I’ve found helpful are:
Vilppu drawing manual, along with the video lectures
Simultaneously, The first 10-20 pages of any book on perspective to give you a rough idea of 1,2 ,3 point perspective to aid you in the goal of drawing boxes using intuition.
Hampton
Anatomy for sculptors
That Tom fox anatomy book is pretty cool.
And lots of copying art from your favourite artists. And lots of figure drawing.

posts.com:
>>6408712
>a single year
>365 days in a year
if we multiply that by any amount of time, we can get a certain number of hours in a year
so
>1 hour == 365 hours total
>2 hours == 730 hours total
>3 hours == 1095 hours total
>4 hours == 1460 hours total
>5 hours == 1825 hours total
>6 hours == 2190 hours total
typically, if we break down skills into their micro-facets, we can learn something in about 25 hours
if we're really bad at that subject, it might take 50 hours but you'll usually achieve ability before that time

for instance, if you wanted to draw hands, it's not going to take you 10,000 hours as some autists suggest but rather 25 to 50 hours total
this is 25 to 50 hours of actual drawing not getting up to get a drink of water and then shit posting on /ic/ and then including that time into your timeframe of drawing

even though, as mentioned before, it wouldn't take 50 hours but lets say it does, here's the progression if we were to learn micro-skills (drawing hands or other very specific things)
>365 hours == 7 micro skills
>730 hours == 14 micro skills
>1095 hours == 21 micro skills
>1460 hours == 29 micro skills
>1825 hours == 36 micro skills
>2190 hours == 43 micro skills
This means that if you do the bare minimum of drawing every single day for at least an hour, you SHOULD have become at least comfortable drawing at least 7 micro skills
hell, even if you split the 7 micro-skills learned in those 365 hours and say that the person did the absolute BARE minimum to learn just ONE micro-skill
>7/2 (30m) == 3.5 micro-skills
>3.5/2 (15m) == 1.75 micro-skills
this means that if you draw for a bare minimum of 15 minutes per day, focusing on a specific micro-skill, you HAVE to at least be good or at least decent at that one ability

there's no way you spend 50 hours drawing Loomis heads (unless you don't understand form, which in that case you need to study perspective and form before learning to draw the human body) and still draw it like shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
January -> Last week
I used to focus too much on form and details instead of movement so my gesture drawings looked really bad. I did a lot of gesture drawings (even 1000 30seconds in one week) till I was able to stop focusing so much on details. I got better but this last month I've been trying to get better at painting so in my recent gestures, even though I try to give movement/force to the poses, I end up focusing more on shapes and shadows.
I know that's not what gesture drawings are for, but I've already done thousands and thousands of them, so I'm okay with not focusing on movement/force and just using them as warm up.
